revised_title: Electrical Discharge and Voluntary Action in Torpedoes
tldr: The author conducted experiments on torpedo fish from the Cape of Good Hope to study their electrical discharge and its relation to their nervous system. They found that the electrical discharge is a vital action dependent on the fish's life and voluntary action. Frequent use of the electrical organs can be injurious to the fish, and the nerves of the electrical organs play a crucial role in the discharge. The author also observed that the fish's voluntary power over the electrical organ may be related to the effects of castration in animals.
